funkatronics.code.tactilewaves.dsp.toolbox

Class FFT

  • java.lang.Object
    • funkatronics.code.tactilewaves.dsp.toolbox.FFT

  • public class FFT
extends java.lang.Object
    Class for performing Fast Fourier Transforms on sample buffers

    Both Complex objects and single/double precision arrays are supported for radix-2 FFT's, as well as lookup based fft/ifft for performance (requires instantiation) Any single/double precision array length is supported for Fourier transformation. A radix-2 fft will always be used if possible, applying Bluestein's algorithm otherwise.

    See Also:
    Complex, Cepstrum, DCT, LPC, MFCC

        public static void complexFFT(float[] ReX,
                              float[] ImX)

        Parameters:

        ImX - the imaginary array
        Throws:

      • LUfft

        public void LUfft(float[] ReX,
                  float[] ImX)
        Performs the FFT on a signal using a lookup table for extra performance. The signal must be represented by a real and imaginary array of equal length. Requires instantiation to pre-compute the sin/cos lookup tables.
        Parameters:
        ReX - the real array
        ImX - the imaginary array
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the length of ReX is != to the length of ImX or if the length of the arguments differs from the length of the lookup tables

      • LUfft

        ReX - the real array
        ImX - the imaginary array
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the length of ReX is != to the length of ImX or if the length of the arguments differs from the length of the lookup tables

      • cconvolve

        public static void cconvolve(float[] ReX,
                             float[] ImX,
                             float[] ReY,
                             float[] ImY)
        Performs the circular convolution of the two specified arrays.
        Parameters:
        ReX - real part of first
        ImX - imaginary part of first
        ReY - real part of second
        ImY - imaginary part of second
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the length of x does not equal the length of y or if the length is not a power of 2

      • cconvolve

        public static void cconvolve(double[] ReX,
                             double[] ImX,
                             double[] ReY,
                             double[] ImY)
        Performs the circular convolution of the two specified arrays.
        Parameters:
        ReX - real part of first
        ImX - imaginary part of first
        ReY - real part of second
        ImY - imaginary part of second
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the length of x does not equal the length of y or if the length is not a power of 2

      • cconvolve

        public static void cconvolve(Complex[] x,
                             Complex[] y)
        Performs the circular convolution of the two specified arrays.
        Parameters:
        x - the first signal array
        y - the second signal array
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the length of x does not equal the length of y or if real and imaginary lengths are not equal
